name: t.A.T.u.
description:
'''t.A.T.u.''' ({{langx|ru|Тату}}, {{IPA|ru|tɐˈtu|pron|Tatu.ogg}}, {{Literal translation|[[tattoo]]}}) are a [[Russian pop]] duo consisting of [[Lena Katina]] and [[Julia Volkova]]. The two started out as part of the children's musical group [[Neposedy]] before being managed by producer and director [[Ivan Shapovalov]] and signing with Russian record label Neformat. t.A.T.u.'s debut album ''[[200 Po Vstrechnoy]]'' (2001) was a commercial success in [[Eastern Europe]], and that resulted in the duo signing with [[Interscope Records]] to release its English-language counterpart, ''[[200 km/h in the Wrong Lane]]'' (2002). The album was certified platinum by the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry|IFPI]] for one million copies sold in Europe and became the first album by a foreign group to reach number one in Japan.{{efn|group=upper-alpha|Although ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' claimed t.A.T.u. as the first non-Japanese act to debut at number one in Japan,<ref>{{cite magazine|date=5 July 2003|title=Hitmakers with a Golden Touch|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3w0EAAAAMBAJ&q=t.a.t.u.+non-japanese&pg=PA52|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Nielsen Holdings|Nielsen Business Media, Inc.]]|volume=115|issue=27|page=52|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> South Korean singer [[BoA]] was the first artist overall to achieve such feat in 2002 with her debut Japanese album ''[[Listen to My Heart (BoA album)|Listen to My Heart]]''—the singer's second Japanese album ''[[Valenti (album)|Valenti]]'' also reached number one on its first week in 2003, one month before t.A.T.u.'s Japanese debut.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2009/03/20/music/no-constrictions-on-boas-ambitions/|first=Robert Michael|last=Poole|title=No constrictions on BoA's ambitions|work=[[The Japan Times]]|date=20 March 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190609020138/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2009/03/20/music/no-constrictions-on-boas-ambitions/|archive-date=9 June 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|date=15 February 2003|title=Hits of the World: Japan (Dempa Publications Inc.; 02/05/2003)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AQ8EAAAAMBAJ&q=japan+boa|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|volume=115|issue=7|page=40|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> According to [[Oricon]], t.A.T.u. became the first foreign group to reach number one with their self-titled Japanese debut album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oricon.co.jp/news/2096758/full/|title=【オリコン】BLACKPINK、アルバム初登場首位デビュー 海外歌手3組目|date=5 September 2017|language=ja|publisher=[[Oricon]]|access-date=28 February 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190228032307/https://www.oricon.co.jp/news/2096758/full/|archive-date=28 February 2019}}</ref> The album had peaked at number three in its first week on the Oricon Albums Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|date=22 March 2003|title=Hits of the World: Japan (Dempa Publications Inc.; 03/12/2003)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fw8EAAAAMBAJ&q=japan+200+km%2Fh|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|volume=115|issue=12|page=72|issn=0006-2510}}</ref>}} It was also certified gold in the United States and included the international hits "[[All the Things She Said]]" and "[[Not Gonna Get Us]]". The duo [[Russia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2003|represented Russia]] in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2003]] with the song "[[Ne ver, ne boysya]]", finishing third. t.A.T.u. is one of the few Russian performers who have achieved international success along with [[Alla Pugacheva]] and [[Anna Netrebko]].

t.A.T.u. released their second international album, ''[[Dangerous and Moving]]'', alongside its Russian equivalent, ''Lyudi Invalidy'', in 2005, with the group reaching moderate success after parting ways with Shapovalov. The former was promoted with the international hit "[[All About Us (t.A.T.u. song)|All About Us]]". The duo ventured into other projects, such as creating their own production company T.A. Music and promoting the film inspired by their story, ''[[You and I (2008 film)|You and I]]'' (2008). Their last pair of albums, ''[[Vesyolye Ulybki]]'' and ''[[Waste Management (album)|Waste Management]]'', followed between 2008 and 2009, respectively. t.A.T.u. officially broke up in 2011, with Katina and Volkova pursuing solo careers. They reunited to perform at special occasions, such as [[2014 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|the opening ceremony of the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi]], in subsequent years.
